Bernard Williams's Critique Of Rationalism In Ethics

Bernard Williams was a moral philosopher, though he did not practice moral philosophy in the traditional sense especially from 1980s onwards. Under the influence of the so-called historical turn in the social sciences, he grew rather increasingly sceptical of "the ideas of rationality embodied in most contemporary moral philosophy" (Williams, 2011: xvi). In particular, he found both utilitarian and Kantian approaches to moral philosophy unable to provide an adequate (i.e. realistic) answer to what he thought one of the most important questions for (moral) philosophy to attempt to answer: "How should one live?" (Williams, 2011: 1) Guided by, what Williams considered, an excessively ambitious promise to provide a "theory" to guide ethical reasoning, much of moral philosophy, he thought, depended on a too robust (i.e. unrealistic) theory of human agency and rationality. As a result, numerous theories that have been proposed in this register have, in practice, only contributed to increasing the gulf between (moral) philosophy and ethical practice, despite their original promise to be action-guiding.

Williams shared with much of analytical philosophy the concern for philosophy's relevance to moral and political practice. As I have already stated, he considered it an important task for philosophy to attempt to answer Socrates's question: "How should one live?" Yet, he thought that to be able to do so successfully philosophy must set out not from a rationalistic but from a realistic account of the powers, skills, concerns and interests of real human agents. Importantly, however, taking human agents as they are, does not, for Williams, issue in fatalism: that is, complete resignation in the face of existing reality. On the contrary, for him it only leads to a more chastened and realistic understanding of the powers of (moral) philosophy. Instead of attempting to provide a "theory" to guide ethical reasoning, he suggested that philosophy should attempt to identify what "makes sense" for real human agents to believe and to do in their given their historical, material conditions.

This chapter will first present William's critique of rationalism in ethics and, then, consider his suggestion for a more limited role for philosophy in terms of what he termed as "making sense". The aim of the chapter is both to reflect on Williams as a philosopher critical of a particular understanding of rationality and to contribute to recent debates on political realism, where Williams figures as one of the key progenitors.
